Okay smarty-pants people. Help me out here. 
 
 Can thorium reactors help in the fight against nuclear terrorism? 
 
 As I understand it, thorium itself cannot be used as a critical mass. Furthermore, thorium reactors use thorium fuel in a way that produces fissionable uranium fuel which is then used to power the reactor. A lot less waste is produced. Terrorists who steal some thorium are SOL as they need a nuclear reactor to breed the uranium. Low enriched reactors can have their fuel stolen and then processed like Iran into HEU which can be used as a weapon. Plus LEU and HEU reactors produce alot more waste. 
 
 it seems IMO that thorium reactors can limit access to fuel as a nuclear weapon and massively reduce waste as a radiological weapon at the same time while fulfilling power needs. 
 
 any problems technically I should know before I put this idea into a paper on weapons of mass destruction & terrorism?
Kronus

This might not directly address your question, but the idea of terrorists stealing nuclear fuel and building an atomic bomb is pretty remote. Nukes are tricky. They take skilled labor, specialized materials (aside from the nuclear material) and are big, bulky things. It takes full fledged countries years of well funded research to be able to make a nuke, it's not something terrorists could do in their garage. What they could do is take stolen nuclear material and just wrap it around a conventional bomb, making a dirty bomb. So if thorium does in fact produce less waste it could help on that score. But the fact that it won't go critical does not, to me, seem to help much in the "war on terrorism".

I don't mean to throw a wrench into this discussion, but as I understand it, a thorium reaction requires a free neutron flux that is only possible from a conventional U-235 or Pu-239 reaction. So you run a conventional reactor and irradiate some thorium and get some fissile isotope of uranium that continues the reaction. That's much like how conventional reactors produce significant amounts of Pu-239 from U-238 by neutron capture.
 
 You don't tell us which isotope. Certainly not all 29 isotopes of thorium are fertile, just as all 24 isotopes of uranium and all 20 isotopes of plutonium are not fissile or fertile. All you tell us is that thorium somehow becomes fissile uranium. Which isotope? Is it neutron capture? Please explain.
 
 Understand that I don't doubt that this is possible. In fact, I am aware that it is possible. I'm actually questioning the trade off.

 It's not used because it would take a big chunk out of the current profit margins of the nuclear industry. Why change over to something that isn't known to be profitable when you have a fat cash cow right now? The French, US and Russians have designed the business models around Uranium and Plutonium reactors. To switch to Thorium would completely screw their investments up and change their core competencies. If I was them, I'd be adamant against Thorium because it threatens my paycheck. Now India has it going on. But they are doing it for completely different reasons. Largely because getting uranium isn't viable as they aren't under the NPT and even the US is sketch as their civilian-military programs are hard to tell apart. They could use their local Thorium sources to breed uranium for weapons. That's basically their goal. Most nations don't have large supplies of thorium.
 
 And you can make weapons from the thorium fuel cycle. It's just a heck of a lot harder and a lot more dangerous. I recall the US only made one and then said screw it it's too damn hard.
